posts.com:
Need some tips with Trev. I had a 75% WR on my way up to Masters doing tons of damage, rarely dying, with both stacking items and focus band, using the usual Curse Horn Leech and bringing in a Potion. But once in Masters (or maybe since the latest patch) I feel like I'm just not doing well anymore, perhaps in part because there are so many auto attackers running rampant and I'm getting shredded incredibly quickly. My WR has fallen to around 50%. I'll do around 40k, still take and and heal a fair bit, but I go down pretty easily and don't feel like I'm making as big a difference as I used to. I'm also finding that I'm struggling to get to 6 stacks when it used to be consistent. I tried switching to X.Speed and it feels more or less the same, I still can't properly get to the backline, and the opposing team rarely have much of a frontline to peel off of my team, so after throwing out my Unite and trying to get to the back where they all use X.Speed and Eject, I'm kind of a sitting duck.

Any tips? I guess in part this would be just in general for Defenders/tanks that don't have much of a way to close the distance quickly.

>>52923855
Unfortunately, there's no real easy fix of an item build/moveset for your situation. You will need to actively think about your positioning and how you'll get close to the enemy. I would suggest playing like a stealth assassin. Bushes are your best friend, and try to imagine an enemy field of sight (usually about a Switch-screen wide) when looking for a route to ambush them from behind. With enough luck you could surprise the enemy into wasting a flash or x-speed without using a unite.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As you walk through the dark forest, you suddenly come face to face with Iron Jugulus, a giant monster with a mouth that can swallow anything whole. You try to run, but it's too late. The Iron Jugulus opens its jaws and you feel yourself being pulled inside.

You struggle and kick, trying to escape, but the walls of the Iron Jugulus's throat are made of solid iron and you can't find any purchase. You feel the monster's stomach acid begin to burn your skin and you know that you have to act fast.

Using all your strength, you manage to pull out your knife and begin to saw at the iron walls of the Iron Jugulus's stomach. It's slow going, but eventually you manage to create a small hole. You squeeze through the opening and fall to the ground, panting and covered in stomach acid.

You look up to see the Iron Jugulus staring down at you with a mix of confusion and anger. You take the opportunity to run as fast as you can, never looking back. You know that you'll never forget the terror of being swallowed whole by the Iron Jugulus, but at least you managed to escape with your life.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Self-Destruct and Explosion should have the same base power but Explosion should be a special fire-type move. They should both keep the defensive stat reducing stealth effect from before the nerf.

“Never miss” moves like Swift should still hit its target during moves like Fly and Dig like they did in Gen 1. It’s less about making sense and more about buffing underused moves for balance in a way that keeps the spirit of the move.

Tackle should have 35 base power with 95 accuracy like it originally had. It’s supposed to be a basic but mediocre move that weak Pokémon start out with. You’re supposed to be happy to get rid of it with something better. Buffing it to 50 is dumb and makes Nuzlocking Gen 5 a pain in the ass.

Bug should be super effective against poison-type like it was in Gen 1. Less about making sense and more about balance since bug-type is so fucking shit.
>make fairy-type
>give them resistance to bug just to make sure bug-type will always be shit
JUST

Moves like Sonic Boom and Dragon Rage should just do damage equal to the user’s move like Seismic Toss and Nightshade. Having a move only do 20 or 40 damage is really worthless outside of the first hour or two in the game. They’re also both equally worthless in competitive regardless of the generation, if that counts for anything.

Rock Smash should drop defense 100% of the time. The move is weak as shit and buffing it wouldn’t make any impact in competitive play. As it stands, the move is a shitty version of Power-Up Punch. And yeah, not everything should be balanced for competitive but shit like Constrict (10 base power?????) should at least work 100% of the time.
>Gen 1: lowers speed; 33% chance
>Gen 2-7: lowers speed; 10% chance
>Gen 8+: the move does not exist
LMAO. I get that some moves are meant to be weak to give them a niche but at least DON’T FUCKING NERF THEIR EFFECT WHEN THEY’RE ALREADY A WORTHLESS MOVE

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>52911327
>What kind of cliffhanger does it end on?
It isn't a cliffhanger per se, but it's only the completion of the first story arc of an originally intended three, so there's a lot of stuff that's clearly setup for later resolution that's left open-ended. (It was supposed to be a graphic novel kind of thing but the original character designer and artist dipped about a dozen pages into the first chapter and the author was nine chapters deep, so finishing the first arc felt like the best compromise between not throwing all the work away and not committing to more than the extant work required.)

The problem/reason for that is that the author is a nerd and actually wrote about a dozen things and they're all set in the same continuity, so even ignoring the bits that were for the intended latter two parts, there's also a lot that references other stuff, including stuff that wasn't yet written when it came out.

All that aside, it's a couple dozen chapters of slice-of-life that takes an objective look at the gardevoir-waifu cliche, starter pokemon loyalty issues, where pokemon fit into a human family structure, the innately speculative fiction aspects of things like parallel worlds and transient land masses (as are canon in Pokemon but of a different sort here), the pressures of organized competition, latent psychic emanations, ghosts with attitude, adverse possession law, wildlife management, identity theft, and treatments for acute hypothermia.

But mostly people click on it because "Gardevoir" is in the tags.

>>52910812
It may no longer be an issue but AO3 used to be notorious for a long sign-up queue. Apply well before you want to post there.

>zwcsp

>The closest was all the way in Sunnyville on the other side of the region. And that was a trip his parents weren’t willing to make.
Are you intending to imply that one must have a Professor-assigned starter to participate in League? Canon has people with pokemon from any origin; the Hero's Journey of Red, Ash, etc. justifies having a pokemon with viable BST.

I feel like this infodump should've been the entirety of Chapter 1 after the funeral scene cold open. As a bulky flashback, you could show rather than tell Travis's efforts to acquire a starter, and time-skip as needed to need only portray "the good stuff." Like, one scene of him trying to get a trip to Sunnyville, another where he's doing yard work to earn money to mail-order some pokeballs and then fails to catch anything with the one/few he gets, and so on. Another where he tries to borrow one and gets told plainly that his acquaintances won't entrust him with the care of their pokemon for several reasons giving him reason to introspect—that could be where he suspends the idea and it lingers and gnaws at him in the background till the expiration of Arcanine.

Instead we're spending a lot of time trying to sell the premise when either the reader is already willing to suspend disbelief for the sake of making acquisition of a starter a momentous (and hitherto belated) event in Travis's life, or it points out the contrivance and makes it more awkward.

The rest of the chapter works well enough, although maybe something more interesting could be done to get them together without it being "that simple." Travis could've lost his keys or phone and had to go back maybe, or leave the encounter a bust but later (after acquiring a starter) Travis goes up the mountain again to grind some levels and encounters it again, and then tries to add it to the roster.

>>52912683
> I really wanted to get things off the ground
The lack of immediate relevance of Travis's backstory prevents it from taking flight. A flashbacks sequence can _show_ the key events leading to Travis being here as he is and feeling the way that he does. Alternatively, the "fill that in later" path, would be to just play the funeral scene straight, have Travis choose to go for a walk instead of to return, and then use the walk as a way to establish. Maybe he sees some "first route" kinds of pokemon and laments that he couldn't even catch one of those when he did manage to get some balls. He could see someone with a quality starter and rue that his parents never agreed to a vacation trip that would include a stop at a Lab. And as he goes deeper into the wild and higher up the hill he could start to realize the danger he's put himself into and _then_ contemplate if even having a starter he might be as unprepared as he is right now. Stuff like that gives lots of opportunity for building tension while establishing backstory while the main story doesn't break stride.

>>52913832
I get what you mean with the pacing, I should really try to stop writing giant chunks of introspection like that. However one thing I can't compromise is the trip into the wilderness being incidental. It's very important that it was a conscious choice, since when I came up with the idea for the story, one of the main themes was to be complacency, and with that, a recurring thematic development of someone wanting to do a thing and then just doing it. I was explicitly trying to fit that kind of development twice into the first chapter just to establish it as strongly as possible, because I had planned to use it for future arcs and other characters, applying it in different ways and so on. That's part of why I was hesitant to open with a big flashback, because it doesn't let me establish the thematics I want quite as strongly out of the gate. I could go way heavier on the complacency, to be sure, but ultimately that would end up not hitting the tone I wanted for this first chapter

In any case, all that introspection is definitely due to get cut up and spaced out to make way for more actual things happening

"... And this is Master Florian. Everyone, please get along with him!"

After being introduced to my homeroom class, I quickly darted my eyes to find a place to sit. Nemona eagerly waved me over, sitting in the back corner of the room. Kind of weird, since I thought she'd be interesting in learning more about Pokemon considering her love of battling. I smiled at her and sat next to her in the back, looking forward with a rush of excitement as class began.

A few minutes in, I heard a weird noise. I looked over, seeing Nemona was making a clicking noise with a mechanical pencil to get my attention. When she saw me, she winked at me and moved her hand--my eyes traveled to follow it. She had unbuttoned one small part of her white school shirt and pulled it forward to show me the inside; I could see one of her boobs. She quickly refastened it and smirked at me.

>>52928426
I try not to use nana so unless a Pokémon is really pissing me off. Like you said, I’ll usually use them for feeding to my buddy or gym Pokémon, but if I really wanna make sure I complete a “ Make 5 curveball great throws in a row” or “Make 3 excellent throws in a row”, I use it on the last or second-to-last remaining skill throw.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52928426
Nanab is maybe only for consecutive throw tasks. It's arguably useful for earning XP, whereas razz berry helps secure the Pokémon capture, and pinap berry expedites evolving and powering up Pokémon.

As you can reliably catch any Pokémon by being patient with your throws and learning how to best do curve balls, Nanabs are pretty useless and are better used as treats for your buddy or gym defenders. It also heals gym defenders more than regular razz or pinap berries.

Never trash berries by the way, put excess into gym defenders. You're allowed to feed 100 berries per 30 minutes, with 30 dust per berry for 3000 stardust, and an estimated 1/80 chance to get a candy from the defending Pokémon.

>Fat shit gets better because 2 of the best stallbreakers in the tier just disappeared, so semi-stall and balance get a massive buff. Full stall is still dogshit
>HO takes a hit from losing these for sure and is going to scramble for replacements ASAP. 1-2 of Moth, Volc, Dirge or Ceruledge will become the go-to Fire types. People try to use Worm to replace Cyclizar but it falls off super quickly and you return to seeing more Glimmora/Grimm style HOs
>People also experiment with Primeape before realizing it's bad
>Speaking of Dirge, it sharply raises in usage since its best counter is gone. Chien Pao also sees a raise
>Sun makes it out okay by swapping to Zard as their Specs nuke
>Gholdengo and Pult become way harder to deal with now that Shadow Ball is essentially free into everything. Kingambit rises as a result of this + losing 2 really good checks into it

If nothing else, what they could do is make use of the real evo mechanic for them. Evolve your Pokemon into Mega, you lose the original Pokemon, but it's Attack is transferred to the Mega (And it comes with a damage multiplier).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52937770
When you make a code change for a project you "push" the changes to copied branch of it where they're saved and available for review, testing, and iteration, but safely separated from the main branch. When your changes are finalized you make a Pull Request to the main branch, requesting that it "pull" the code from your branch. The PR gets reviewed, tested, and approved by people with permissions on the project before it gets merged.

For anyone who can help me who isn't familiar with how sprites need to be formatted to work for this.

>The front picture will need to be a png file with only four colors and a size of either 40x40, 48x48, or 56x56 pixels. The back picture is a 32x32 file, however the image itself is 28x28 pixels, with the bottom and rightmost four rows left blank. This is because the 28x28 image will be scaled up by 2 to fill the 56x56 space, but the dimensions of the file must be a multiple of 8.

This reminds me of a story: one time a horse got offended a porcupine said hello to him (it was an arrogant prick, so nobody should try to talk to him like a commoner).
He wanted vengeance, but needed help because the porcupine escaped, and he asked help to a human.
They team up, prepare a trap, the human mounts the horse, they kill the porcupine. Now here's the kicker: the horse said "thanks human, now you can leave", but he never left his mount.
Over time, the horse's species became enslaved by the human, and now he is forced to work FOR him, forever.

It's an tale that teaches you that if you are arrogant/weak, and you ask for help, be wary people tries to conquer you.

>>52923578
No plans to add more. I did this because I saw Gym Leader Matt's Gardevoir solo run & I couldn't get Sanqui to work for me. It kept randomizing gen 1 only as starter choices.

So I looked at the github page for pokered assembly for the 1st time ever, installed the required tools to get it work, & read the tutorials so I knew which .asm files to change. This was also my 1st time ever coding anything in assembly.

I grabbed the sprite from the video, resized it to fit, and had to find a plugin for paint.net that would simplify the existing sprite into only 4 colors. I converted it into a 4 color black and white. (Assembly instructions later add the green color if you are playing in full color mode.)

I used a gen 3 learnset for her limited to just the gen 1 attacks except she learns Growth when she would learn Calm Mind because Growth works the same as Calm Mind in gen 1.

She replaces Charmander in Oak's lab only. (He's still in the game.) but I could easily have her replace the other 2 instead. Starting with Ralts instead would also be possible if I just add the code for Ralts & Kirlia, but it wasn't what I was going for here.

I'm guessing she shows up as the first mon on the title screen because I had her replace Charmander. It was a complete accident but I was so happy when the game booted up and she was the first thing I saw on the title screen.

I spent about 6 hours doing all of this. The github tutorial was pretty straightforward, but I still had to trial & error some things.

I have no idea how to add a cry. Using asm it seems like cries are just a text file of numbers and each number has something to do with what pitch is played and for how long until the next pitch. It looks like standard audio files aren't used at all anywhere. Using one of the unused cries may be easier, but I'd like to figure out how to recreate her actual cry if I can.

Other than the cry, I have a fully functioning gen 1 Gardevoir. Not bad for 1/4 a day of work.

>>52936439
Crystal's was a mea culpa for it being a JPN-only event back in 2000 (fun fact, Japan cannot legitimately obtain Celebi in the VC releases, as their Celebi event was a mobile GB exclusive). they didn't do anything, but set a flag to allow players to obtain the ball.
There is no such event or encounter for Mew, it wasn't even planned for release, until Morimoto shoved it in in the very last filespace available to him when they took the Gen 1 debug tools out. There was no way to establish a specific encounter for it, as all they were doing was plugging its code into an official emulator to run it.

>When should I eat food?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52879198
>If Square Enix made Pokemon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52883091
Eat food when you need a specific effect like encounter power to find a rare spawn easier, raid power to get bonus rewards from raids, etc.
Custom sandwiches are the best since you can make basically any type and ability combo you want. The premade recipe book is good for main game and searching for a specific ability if you don't know how the sandwich system works.
Buy ingredients like whenever, I would buy like 10 of everything you don't have yet when you see it.

Eventually if you want to go for shinies, these recipes attached are convenient. There's a dozen different resources scattered around online for other more specific recipes, so just Google search for a specific ability + type if you're curious or try to theory craft a sandwich at this link
https://cecilbowen.github.io/pokemon-sandwich-simulator/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For a few games now, GF has been buffing some of the lamer abilities. Like giving a lot of the crappy Gen 3 ones that just blocked Confusion/Attrraction or whatever the additional ability to block Intimidate, as an example. So what other ones would you tweak?

>Magma Armor
Becomes more like a defensive Water Bubble. Still blocks Freeze but also heavily reduces damage from Water and Ice moves (taking them to 0.25x damage, treating them as a double resist)
Why?: Only two lines get it and both are kind of garbage right now. This gives them an opportunity to mitigate a 4x weakness by cutting it by a quarter, making it a neutral hit, and then making Ice attacks deal 1/8 damage, as they naturally resist already. It doesn't radically change Magcargo into a good Pokémon, but it does have more chances to do something. Camerupt may benefit a lot more actually becoming more viable on different types of teams as a "Snow" counter or a good utility mon on Sun and Sand teams

>Corrosion
Still let's you poison Poison and Steel types, but now also works like Scrappy to let you ingore Steel's immunity to Poison moves altogether
Why?: It's kind of weird it doesn't work like this already. The Salazzle line doesn't really need this buff, but a special attacking Glimmora (rather than a suicide lead) becomes a lot more viable.

>Mycelium Might
Additionally lets your spore and powder moves hit Grass types
Why?: Another one that should probably just work like this anyway. Currently this ability is kind of garbage since it forces you to go last and the most frequent move you would be using, Spore, is already going to hit 90% of the things you're using it on. Might as well let it hit Grass types too

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52929340
Any ability that provides immunity to a status should now also provide bonus type 'resists', to match with purifying salt.
Magma armor reducing damage from Ice/Water movies is a good example. But you could also do a similar thing with Oblivious and Fairy moves, or Insomnia/Vital Spirit to shrug off psychic attacks. Immunity, Limber, and Water Veil helping against Poison, Electric, and Fire would also be a given.

I don't know if it'd make any mons with those abilities too crazy, since most of those with them have better options.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52929340
>Hyper Cutter
Prevents Attack lowering AND now buffs power of "claw" moves
Why?: Blocking Intimidate is kind of neat but all the Pokémon with this ability aren't very viable, which is a shame. Let's make it like Sharpness and recategorize a bunch of moves as "claw" moves. The actual description of this ability currently mentions you get the ability because you have a powerful pincer/claw. So some moves would have crossover with Sharpness, like X-Scissor, but there would also be uniquely claw moves like Crabhammer, Vice Grip and Crush Claw. Does this help a lot of Pokémon become more viable? Probably not. But I just really want to see Kingler and Mawile not be shit again.

>Big Pecks
Prevents Defense lowering AND now buffs the power of wind and wing moves (because you're using your big pectoral muscles to flap those wings of yours that make the wind, obv)
Why?: A lot of Pokémon have this ability circa Generation 5 and 6, then they pulled way the fuck back and I think only one new Pokémon has it since. It would be neat for the bird Pokémon who have this to actually get some benefit from it rather than just an immunity to defense dropping that doesn't really matter for them because they're not very defensive. Getting a buff to wind and wing moves would be nice. And the only reason I included wing moves is because they're so few why the fuck not?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52929372
I feel like those changes would only help competitive. There's a lot of abilities running around now that play with type effectiveness but not a lot of older Pokémon have access to them. That would be the fix and it generally would probably make them more surprising to play against

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The abilities that don't do anything in battle should all be given an actual purpose.

>Illuminate
Lowers the evasion of all Pokemon on the field by one stage. This goes hand in hand with the out-of-battle effect of making Pokemon easier to find by illuminating the area.
You now want to use Illuminate Starmie with Hydro Pump, Thunder and Blizzard.

>Run Away
The Pokemon can always switch out in trainer battles regardless of trapping abilities or moves. It baffles me how this is not already the case.

>Ball Fetch
The Pokemon can use Fling repeatedly without losing its item. This is a meme buff obviously but I still think it would be funny.

>Honey Gather
If the Pokemon is holding Honey, it will consume it at 25% health or less, restoring 50% of its max HP. At the end of every turn there is a 50% of the consumed Honey being replaced by a new one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Stall
Additional effect where this Pokemon holds off taking damage during the turn until it has finished attacking. This way it's not a complete dud. You're guaranteed to get something off before going down. The ability would activate when it gets hit and then the HP bar doesn't drop until after it moves. It could still take passive damage though, I guess

>Forewarn
Pokémon now still warns you about the strongest move of the adjacent opponent, instead of a random opponent in a double battle. The Pokemon is now then also guaranteed to avoid all damage the first turn right after switching in. This will help Pokémon like Jynx, Hypno and Musharna guarantee they can get off that boost or status move the first turn.

>Anticipation
The Pokémon still shudders if the opponent has a SE move or OHKO move, but now the ability activates every time either the user switches is in or an opponent does. Every time it shudders, it also gains a +1 Speed boost sorta like Rattled. Every one of the Pokémon that gets this ability has something else it would rather run, but it may have a niche use for some things. For example, DDing Whiscash can come in and guarantee it will be fast enough to get off the DD. Or something like Toxicroak, which has somewhat decent coverage, can be sort of a twisted revenge killer that doesn't have to rely on Sucker Punch to "out speed" a Psychic or Flying type.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52929340
gonna give some solid buffs to some real stinkers

>Heavy Metal
On top of doubling weight, also halves damage from Fighting-type moves.
Why?: Pretty obviously, a thicker, heavier metal is a lot harder to break with your bare hands than something lighter.

>Light Metal
On top of halving weight, also halves damage from Ground-type moves.
Why?: This one's technically a bit of a stretch, as ironically weaker earthquakes typically affect smaller buildings more than larger buildings, while larger buildings are more likely to be damaged by severe earthquakes.
But "light" metal could also be interpreted as being a more flexible material, which would in fact be able to better absorb shockwaves than something more rigid.

>Keen Eye
Boosts accuracy upon entering battle.
Why?: Because it makes more sense for something with strong eyes to have a greater accuracy advantage than to simply be better at coping with sand getting flung into its eyes.

>Hyper Cutter, Big Pecks
Now also prevents the user from lowering their Attack/Defense respectively
Why?: They're already direct downgrades from something like Clear Body, might as well give it SOME kind of niche given that they're almost always paired with far better abilities anyways

>Anticipation
Raises speed if the foe has a super effective move.
Why?: Because Anticipation is garbage and learning whether your opponent has a coverage move against you is not worth sacrificing a real ability (which given its almost always paired with a far better ability, is usually the case)

>>52936946
You're welcome but there's a bit of a learning curve to shiny hunting on union circle on area zero, but basically we split sandwiches (or use the same, depending on your version) and we each go to a specific pokemon or two that we hunt.
Once we find it, we tell the others.

The person who found it, to whom that exclusive belongs (ie roaring moon for the scarlet player) saves in front but never engages it, while one of the, for example, 2-3 violet players can catch it.

The scarlet player can then restart and since the shiny originated on his character, it will be waiting for him.

Just turn off auto save and don't engage unless told to.


Any questions and the violet player might be able to answer them while I get some food.

I love Gengar’s entire vibe. >>52934794
Absol. First of all, it has a damn yin yang symbol for a head. It has pretty big paws and is fluffy. Its face is simple, yet has some subtle touch of human-like traits (more so in mega form) while maintaining some animalistic traits too. In a way, the head/body combo reminds me a bit of a sphinx. It can give some pretty striking stare thanks to its red eyes too.
The mega form becomes extra fluffy and gets gorgeous angel-like wings.
Canonically, it can have a bad reputation because people thought it brought disaster with itself. But it was actually bringing warnings before disaster strikes. Makes it kinda misunderstood and mysterious.
It's pretty strong attack wise too.

If you're suggesting the person switching them did so with knowledge of their contents, then they've been tampered with and no longer reflect the true random odds.

Otherwise it would just happen to be a statistical anomaly. The person switching out the packs still has the same odds of picking out the packs to be switched as you would if you picked one to open. That's why I said I don't trust 300 packs a sufficient sample size. A large sample size means a lower ratio of statistical irregularities and a more accurate measurement of the odds.

https://www.siliconera.com/funny-stories-of-pokemon-english-name-localizations/
>Seth McMahill, Assistant Manager of Product Marketing at Nintendo, has been working exclusively on Pokémon games throughout his career at the company.
>When we spoke with McMahill recently, we asked if he had any interesting or amusing stories to tell from his days localizing the older games. McMahill recalled a couple of instances for us.
>“When you’re naming them, you’re together in a room with a counterpart from NCL (Nintendo Co. Ltd.),” McMahill shared. “We would basically have a thesaurus, a whiteboard on the wall, and would lock ourselves in for days on end, and the days would turn into months.”
>He continued: “The craziest one is… my wife was about to have a baby. So I’m at home, going through baby name books. I’m at work, going through baby name books, along with thesauruses and dictionaries. And after a while, stuff starts to sound weird. So, we had Piplup (Japanese name: Pochama), and the description from Japan was: ‘the sound of a small pebble in the water’. That was what we had to come up with.”
>McMahill recalls: “What we came up with was Piploop, which sounded like ‘poop’.”
>“And we didn’t even think of that,” he says. “No one thought of it. And we were talking to another group, saying we’d finally figured it out, and they went: ‘Poop?’ They said it sounded like poop. And I said, ‘It does not sound like poop! You don’t know what you’re talking about; I’ve been doing this for years!'”
>“And then, finally, after a good night’s rest, I thought: ‘That does sound like poop…’ So, we ended up with Piplup, which was the final name.”

The stadium was loud and I had felt so proud, but a disinterested expression is all her face allowed. Their unexpected love burns us all, but not in the same way, not at all. Him with passion, her with desire and I with a need so dire. The baby cries and I remember that time flies. She fell for the first time, her first steps were to her a treacherous climb. The proud parents held her in their arms, not allowing her to know any other harms. Tears fell from everyone's eyes, the baby's from the fright, the parents from delight and mine from all my lies. This is not my life, the baby's not my blessing and I am not his wife.

>>52927676
https://www.renpy.org/doc/html/quickstart.html
Renpy is so simple it's basically not even a coding language. To make a functional VN you only need to know like four things
>how to play music
>how to show a background
>how to show and hide a character sprite
>how to display some dialog/narration

Renpy's documentation is really thorough and a little obtuse and tautological in my opinion, but any time you need to know how to do something that you can't figure out on your own, you can just google it and find the answer on either the Renpy forum or Renpy subreddit. If you know how to code in Python you can make Renpy do all sorts of complicated stuff but it's not remotely necessary.

>>52934892
Pulling apart some of the code and looking at the game's file structure, it looks like this game wanted to have like 29 characters with a "route." Assuming that a "route" has the typical length and complexity of a major character in a visual novel, the idea that a small team of indie devs could pull this off is as insane as it is pathetic. Just for comparison, how many story routes are in a big-budget game with hundreds of pros working on it full-time, like say, Mass Effect? Nevermind all the coding and art assets, just WRITING 29 full routes in the same game and having them be remotely appealing, coherent, and playable is just a laughable idea. Good riddance to this chicanery, I'm glad I didn't know about it until well after it was abandoned.

VNAnon delivers a superior product because he doesn't try to promise us the second fucking coming of Jesus. He says he'll give us cute pokegirls, and he gives us cutepokegirls. End of story. I'll take a single complete and coherent A New Dawn over a half-baked overambitious joke of a project like PLA any day.

posts.com:
Regardless of whether or not its modern, it's distinctly worse. Defining every member of a particular pokemon species as having a specific job or personality trait severely cripples the degree to which a player can feel like the one they caught is distinctly theirs.
That was the purpose behind things like natures and IVs, where the pokemon you caught could be Timid while your friend's was Brave.

That's especially egregious when it comes to species that the vast majority of players will catch and use. Not everyone will get their hands on a Palafin, but for starters or early route pokemon? It's incredibly strange when they all end up feeling identical because they're loaded up with too many specific personality traits or human features.

This thread is for the growth of artists and those who draw for fun. If you're going to give critique, please do it constructively. Rude or blunt critiques won't help anybody.

Requesters are free to request what they wish, but avoid bumping your request every half hour as it's only going to put people off; try giving it a few hours or more.

Please provide references in ONE image, especially when requesting something outside of the Pokémon universe. If you request something from the old Drawthread or a separate thread, COPY & PASTE the actual request instead of posting a link.

Also, be mindful that requests are done at the discretion of the artists, not on a first come first serve basis.

Please remember to save any piece of art you like from these threads, as we may never know when the archive will start deleting images again. Artists can and are recommended to post their works on other outlets for archival purposes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52933942
1. I was excited because it was the first new game announcement I actually got to see online instead of hearing about it via word of mouth. I remember being confused but intrigued when the names of the starters popped up in multiple different languages, and thought it would carry over into every next starter reveal as standard.

2. I chose Fennekin because I had really bad taste as a kid and was two steps away from being groomed by furries. Didn't know how it'd turn out and got upset when it turned into a witch but mine was male. Today it's hard to choose since I don't love any of the lines, but I'd probably go for Froakie instead (if not box the starter altogether). Frogadier's neat, I like the frubbles.

3. Tragedies, honestly.
There's obviously an attempt at doing "deeper" themes with the story, though it's all so obviously rushed and atrociously paced. Probably the only versions that were completely and actively screwed by being shoved aside so so quickly- they almost feel like a proto-SwSh, with how quickly they were shat out and forgotten about by the company itself. Maybe BW's reception burned Masuda that hard.
Kalos itself feels like a mess of a region with several memorable locations but 0 cohesive fabric stitching them all together.
The new Pokedex is fine- definitely one of the better ones, but kind of blends together in my brain somehow.
Wifi shit was THE best part by far, sole reason I maxed out my playtime on Y and AS respectively. Trying to complete the entire national dex purely via wonder trading was a blast, and I nearly managed it too.

Honestly, I think it's the only 3D era that actually introduced new things without taking such massive steps backwards that they invalidated everything good they tried to add. Pokemon Amie, Super Training, the PSS system, character customization- all worthwhile additions that stuck around and were good concepts from the get-go, as opposed to the shitty one-and-dones we've been getting since ORAS onwards.

>>52933942
>1: What is your reaction to the announcement?
Happy to finally see the main series go to 3D models
>2: Which starter did you pick?
Froakie
>3: How do you feel of the games now?
For better or worse, it's probably my favorite 3D gen. I always thought Kalos was nice, but the further we go the more I start to miss its visual presentation and how the cities or landmarks were designed. If they ever re-release this game, I wouldn't even mind if they stuck to the top-down style of gameplay and just fleshed out the map.

As a game it brought a-lot to the series which I didn't expect, but loved. "Immersion" things like your avatars or the whole affection system. Megas were fun addition, and whatever they've tried to replace it with just hasn't been the same as getting that direct upgrade. And all the multiplayer stuff was good and long overdue. The worst part of the game is just the difficulty, not having any cool superbosses or casual filter fights like past gens. Gen 2 has Red, Gen 3 has Battle Frontier, Gen 4 has Cynthia, Gen 5 has PWT. They were afraid of kids giving up, so they gave up on doing cool battles like before. It's the biggest upset, since XY gives you so many tools to finally make good Pokemon (like Super Training or Exp. Share)? But you don't actually need them to fight anybody.

They shouldn't have cancelled the sequel.

>reminder that serperior is a plant before it is a snake, that it photosynthesizes for nutrition instead of eating...
First of all, we've literally seen wild Serperior eat things before (see pic related). Not to mention the fact that Serperior has a mouth and fangs (which wouldn't make sense on an animal that isn't a consumer).
Second of all, plants cannot produce everything they need through photosynthesis alone. Photosynthesis merely produces sugars which provide energy. The actual nutrients that a plant needs such as iron and calcium must be taken from the environment. Most plants do this using roots, while some plants also use others means... such as eating live prey.
>that every dex entry in its evolution line-up states this
Serperior's dex entries never state that it solely relies on photosynthesis. It would be pretty strange if it did, considering that it's been depicted eating stuff as I mentioned earlier.

>>52901250
Tbh I don't think I do anything special, ever since I was a toddler it's grown really fast (even when I was born I already had my head fully covered lol). My mom also has really long hair so I'm guessing it's genetic. It's currently at 103cm more or less, last year it had a sudden growth spurt out of nowhere (was at like 96 before), don't know why. If it helps, I use Elvive shampoo and conditioner, though sometimes (like twice a month because it's expensive and I need it to last) for the latter I use Tio Nacho instead. I also don't brush very often actually so I'm not constantly pulling at it, and when I do it's very gentle (start from the bottom/tips, with your other hand grab just a bit above it so you don't pull, once that's done grab a bit higher and brush again, continue until you're brushing all of it).
It does become a bit bothersome at times, like getting it stuck in handles without me noticing and having my head pulled back, accidentally sitting on it, bending over and the tips touching the floor (awful if it's wet... ), but other than that it's really nice and I want to see how long it can get tbqh. I can wrap it like a scarf during winter, or feel like some forest fairy when I'm naked at home and it falls all over my body, idk it's just really nice and soft, I can also do a lot of hair dos which is fun.

>what are your thoughts on dudunsparce?
I approve wholeheartedly. Hell, I laughed my ass off when it was datamined and sent it to everyone I knew.

It retains the lovable dopiness of the original, continues the line as weird Japanese cryptids (Tsuchinoko to Nozuchi), stays true to the original gimmick (rare yet unremarkable) thanks to the variable segments, and pisses off the people who hopped on liking Dunsparce ironically because they wanted it to turn into something conventionally cool when it finally evolved. It's the evolution Dunsparce deserved, no matter what most people may think.

>>52918165
Imagine you're a 10-year-old. You're going on a week-long road trip to a family reunion where you aren't going to know anybody and because of a mixup you don't have any book or games for your gray brick Gameboy. All you have is the Gameboy itself, spare batteries, and the one game you happened to leave in it... which you saved up allowance for weeks to buy then realized you didn't like. There's literally nothing to do but play it. And play it. And play it.

This game is my personal hell.

Are there worse Pokemon games? Undoubtedly, but I've been lucky enough to avoid them.

KIDS. DON'T. PLAY. POKÉMON

Since pokemon invoked the existence of a multiverse a couple generations back, you can say that G/S/C takes place in a different universe/timeline from HG/SS. Or you could just decide that G/S/C is 100% noncanon and is fully replaced by the similar-but-slightly-different HG/SS content. Either way the idea of steel types being " recently discovered" doesn't work if you allow for the type chart to be something that exists within canon rather than a game extraction, because then the nature of reality somehow changes as pokemon researchers discover things. The setting turns into madness where subjective reality trumps scientific rigor and it gets worse then harder you try to make it make sense. Best to just ignore the retcon.

In Emerald in particular the gym leaders are way more daunting than they are in any other pokemon game. Details such as

You can always one shot both of Brock's mons if you have a grass or water mon, but against Roxanne even IF you're using any of the water or grass type mons you can get before her, you're not likely to be able to take out her nosepass in 1 or even 2 hits since it's pure rock, and has amazing special defense. That plus the berry and her 2 potions buy her enough Longevity that she actually get's to land some hits on you, making her at least not feel like a push over.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52934584
In prior generations, yes. As of SV, however, it's determined by the level at which you encounter a Pokemon, be that trading or catching something high level without badges. For example, you could go catch something far north like around the lake like Lv 45 Tatsugiri without any badges, but it will not obey you until you get 5 gym badges.
I tested the edge cases specifically and the moment you get the badge that encompasses the level you met the pokemon at be it catching or trading, it will obey, even if it's now higher than that level cap.
I got the Lv 45 Titan Iron Treads after beating its Titan fight in the desert, disobeying me, but I kept it anyway. It racked up XP to level 48 before I got my fifth gym badge, and then it obeyed.
This weird edge case of the level obeying is completely new to SV since this doesn't work in past games.

>>52932985
It has everything to do with the dex cut because Tera typings aren't coming back. There's no way they're going to devote any time or effort into integrating it into any future titles when that time and budget would be better spent propping up whatever new generational gimmick they're developing, especially when they've shown that they'll get rid of far more straightforward or important concepts for less. So mons that relied on Terastalyzing to be good in SV are going to be rendered impotent in gen10.
Terastalyzing represents the jumping-off point for importing old mons where any further advancements along the timeline just isn't worth it anymore.
If you have a really great Hydreigon that you've been moving from game to game since B&W, its performance is only going to get worse after losing the ability to change its typing. It will continue to lose access to useful coverage moves, it will steadily decline in performance as power creep sets in, and whether or not it can be redeemed by some future feature is a complete gamble. You can either leave your mons behind in a game where they're good or hell, even exist, and they can continue to be good and to exist for as long as you have that game; or you can keep dragging them through the mud while reminiscing about how good they used to be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912347
If you do a sandwich together, everyone has to throw in at least one ingredient and one seasoning (though it really doesn't matter too much) then everyone makes it together on a mega sandwich. Everyone shares the same boosts for that sandwich, and making an individual sandwich on your own will only give yourself the boosts.
Usual strat is one player puts in herbs, everyone hunts and then that player resets if they didn't get what they want so nobody has to use up any.

Whenever I encounter a shiny in Scarlet or Violet, I Google "Pokémon Name sv", e.g. "Riolu sv".

"sv" is a quick way to get Serebii's entry for that Pokémon in Scarlet/Violet loaded, and then check the wild Pokémon's learnset for its current level, as well as abilities that may be a factor.
E.g. I can't spore an insomniac Murkrow.
Specifying "sv" is to avoid getting entries for other games like SwSh, or other sites like Bulbapedia. It's specific to the game I'm playing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52922302
Flutter Mane is the only Ghost type in the entirety of AZ, and the caves/underground spots it can spawn are all one big pool so there aren't any other groups for it to choose from. What this means is that it can ONLY spawn the Ghost type, Flutter Mane, if you have a Ghost level 3 Encounter.
The issue presented is that Flutter Mane, like most ghosts, will despawn during the day time. When it's day, they'll technically be spawning in constantly but the game will forcibly despawn them before you can see them (unless you use the lock-on feature, at which point you can watch them fade away). It turned to day during your last 5 minutes so none of them could appear.
This is actually the optimal Flutter hunting method, as shinies are (mostly) hard-coded to not disappear through usual methods and thus when a shiny Flutter is spawned during the day then the game will not despawn it. You can just AFK in AZ and the game will constantly reroll until shinies for you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52922583
Every Pokemon that gets spawned is part of an individual player's spawns, meaning that each one is tied to your game. So being in a Scarlet Union won't make a Violet player spawn Scarlet exclusives, and if both a Scarlet and Violet player were in the same area then both exclusives can spawn but each one "belongs" to each player (meaning if one were to leave the area or Union, their spawns would disappear). Essentially, this means that a Scarlet playing wanting to catch a Violet exclusive will have to have a Violet player find the shiny then call the Scarlet player to come over. You also generally do not want to be in the same place so that you know whose spawns are whose, which is relevant for one of the shiny hunting tricks.
With that said, the general methods are:
>player A resets for an outbreak of exclusive mon, player B hops into the Union and just does the outbreak like normal until required result
>all players of a union share a sandwich with one contributing the herbas (usually host for convenience), so everybody gets that sandwich's boosts and if host gets nothing they can just reset and remake the union - then just shiny hunt like normal
>when you encounter a shiny, you can save then have another player encounter it - when the other player is in battle, close and reload the game to reload the shiny and duplicate it (the person who spawned it CANNOT be the one to encounter it, as it being their spawn means that they are the only one who can respawn it upon reloading)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52922963
You'll either want to do
>share a sandwich of the same type, both hunt for a paradox of that type on your own and call each other over when one finds one
>share a sandwich, one person looks for that type of paradox while the other fucks off to do some other pokemon of a similar type - maybe you have a glimmet outbreak while violet player hunts moth or something
>do your own individual sandwiches, same as first option where you just hunt one normally and call the other player
>only one person hunts at a time, this way the other player can catch shinies and the hunter just resets to get the herbs back

As for the whole duplicating thing, it's whoever spawns in the Pokemon. It's tied to that player, so that player is the only one who can respawn it. Any other player can be the one to encounter it (only one though), as long as the player who spawned it doesn't.
In simpler terms, it'd be like if you could gift somebody a Pokemon then reload your save to get that Pokemon back on your account. Just in this case instead of owning the pokemon, you "own" the spawn to it, like when you reload a shiny outside of a Union.

>And do you happen to know if hunting in separate locations kills spawn rates because I've heard that a lot.
Probably a misconception. Every player can only spawn a max of 7 or so while in a Union (I think it goes down to 5 in AZ?). When you're together it might appear as if more are spawning in, but that's just because each player's spawns are appearing in that same area. In fact being in the same area might actually be something that kills spawn rates, assuming the game can't handle all of them in the same area and enforces the usual cap of 15 wild mons rendered at any time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52928545
Normally sizes are scaled with a heavy bias towards average size and an increasingly rare chance for each size up/down, but meal power makes it an equal chance for any size within a specific range.

If you're hunting a min/max size encounter with Teensy and Humongo power it's a 1/128, 1/96 and 1/64 chance respectively using levels 1, 2 and 3.

posts.com:
First, I just wanted to say you're based for questioning yourself and if you grew up too much rather than blaming the games/troons/TPCi/whoever your boogeyman of choice is.

Second.. yeah, that happens. Sometimes you just grow out of something and stop feeling the same connection. It happens, that's life. You don't have to force yourself to keep playing the same games or franchise - if you still like the monster catching genre or competitive aspect, there's probably other similar games for you to try.

If you simply don't enjoy Pokémon's concepts, you don't have to play it anymore. That doesn't mean you have to give up on it - you can just leave your 3DS and SM carts in a corner, and come back to the franchise some day when you feel like having a nostalgia trip or if for some reason you feel like playing again.

You can step away from a game, an activity, or an hobby without having to fully give it up forever. You don't have to keep playing a game, doing an activity or partaking into an hobby if you don't feel like it anymore.

What matters is that you have fun. If you keep playing them by habit without any fun, it's perfectly fine and healthy to take a step back from them, even if it's only temporary.

>Sometimes I feel that I'm just trying to force my childhood memories back to life and I dont actually enjoy Pokemon that much anymore.
This is also my reason why I care less to this series nowadays.
Despite I prefer the gen 3-5 games for their better gameplay, in the last years I realized to be a Genwunner. The thing that I loved the most about this series was the feeling of doing a journey in a urban-fantasy world that's really similar to ours but there are a lot of bizarre creatures with magical power that you can catch and train and I believe that the first gen (and its sequel) executed this concept the best. Even since gen 2 you can see that GF created the new Pokémon around the console limitations.
I like how gen 3 and 4 tried to use the remaining ideas related to the original Pokémon version of Japan but on the other end I'm not a fan of the vast amount of mythology that got introduced during the periodwhere Masuda was the director. Then the multiverse made everything to messy.
It's like that this series is being soft-rebooted every one or two generation but it's never something official (even if BW could be a proper reboot). No fucking wonder every Pokémon fan has its own headcanon

I've been putting effort into distancing myself from Pokemon during this Generation. I'm tired of always feeling tired, annoyed, pissed, angry and bitter.
Gen 8 was a complete and total lowpoint for me regarding this. Galar was shit. Journeys was shit. BDSP was shit. Only Legends was half of a saving grace.
Galar was specially shit. I seriously hate Galar and that that shitstain of Region and everything on it will forever be a part of the franchise kills me inside.
But even with Gen 9 even if there's some things that when you think about think weren't "Gen 8 problems" but "problems on the franchise as a whole that were exacerbated and felt even bigger just by how BAD Gen 8 bad".

Don't let yourself be gaslighted by "this is just a kids franchise hurr you are not the audience anymore durr" either when anyone half a brain can see all the pandering they do specifically directed at older fans.
If you are not blind you can easily see how the priorities, the handling, the philosophies, of the franchise have changed.
And you are all within your right to dislike that and to not want to like Pokemon anymore, because Pokemon is plain and simply a different now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Potential Status Rework:
So some baseline concepts I set out to address:
>Sleep: if abusable, is a pain in the ass.
Original gamefreak fix: lower accuracy of sleep moves, greatly limit distribution of consistent sleep. Issue mostly hinges on the inability to act coupled with RNG of when you wake.
>Paralysis: Sleep's shithead cousin
Use as a slowdown status is great, but the RNG chance to do nothing at all makes paralysis inconsistent and makes the rewards for inflicting it not something to plan around.
>Freeze: Sleep but different (they really were preoccupied with ways to take away turns in Gen 1, weren't they?)
A status with no status move, meaning it MUST be inflicted by chance. Underutilized, RNG-reliant. I think I've seen two dozen actual Freezes in my entire career, and I've played since Gold release.
>Burn: Okay status
No notes.
>Poison: Toxic is good but limited in use, and base poison is pretty shit
These are the focuses of my initial rework, as I was not too preoccupied with volatile status like Confusion or Attraction - they occupy the same niche as Paralysis, and get more complex.
I set out with the intention to make status less of an RNG fest and more of a conscious choice and reward.

So my first thoughts were to incorporate the changes proposed by PLA.
>Drowsy
Excellent mechanic, but again leans on the RNG aspect. I've removed this and adapted it.
>Frostbite
Fixed Freeze. No way about it. Excellent design.

And I came up with a system to inflict status to allow more ways to interact with them without needing to fuck around with actual status moves or random chance effects.

1/?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912369
>Sleep
Grass types are immune to drowsy / sleep
>No point system. Solely tied to status moves. Moves that would inflict Sleep now inflict Drowsy. Drowsy Pokemon hit with these moves are put to Sleep.
This makes Sleep an easily achievable goal two-punch goal, and balances the opportunity cost of the status with the potential benefit to be gained.
>Drowsy
>Drowsy Pokemons' moves have a flat 10% accuracy reduction (for example, a 90% accuracy move is now 80% accuracy). Additionally, Drowsy Pokemon take 25% increased damage from the next hit they receive after becoming Drowsy
An immediate payoff for investing the time to inflict Drowsy, but nothing crazy.
>Sleep
Sleep turns now follow this setup:
>Turn 1: Fast Asleep, no chance to awake. Moves like Sleep Talk still work.
>Turn 2: 65% chance to wake, move used on waking has 75% of base accuracy. This works out to turn 2 being a 50/50 of waking AND hitting your waking move.
>Turn 3: 100% chance to wake, no changes to accuracy
>Pokemon leaving Sleep are returned to Drowsy status, and cannot be put to Sleep for 3 turns.
>Accuracies of moves used against Sleeping Pokemon are increased by a flat 5%.

So, now Sleep is a telegraphed, earned status that has a lot going on under the hood rather than just being "you can't move for 2-4 turns". This all works out to:
>Invest two turns to put an opposing Pokemon to sleep
>As a result, it is expected the opposing Pokemon will have approx. 1.5 of the next 3 turns to use, a net loss of 1-2 turns.
>And even after waking, the Pokemon remains weakened in a Drowsy state.

This is all a little heavily designed, but Sleep really wasn't well thought-out and never has been. Hiding behind low-accuracy moves doesn't change how busted sleep is fundamentally.

2/?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912381
>Paralysis
Fighting types are immune to dazed/paralysis
>No longer centered around electric types - now based around Flinches and Critical Hits
This makes Paralysis an evergreen status, something heavily needed by non-elemental types.
>Dazed
>Pokemon that have been flinched or critically hit become dazed. Dazed Pokemon lose 25% Speed. Moves used against Dazed Pokemon have increased critical hit ratios. Flinching or Critting a Dazed Pokemon pushes this status to Paralyzed
>Paralyzed
>Speed reduced 50%, Priority moves used by Paralyzed Pokemon lose 1 priority.
>Moves against Paralyzed Pokemon have even higher critical hit ratios
>Accuracies of moves used against Paralyzed Pokemon are increased by a flat 10%

This makes Paralysis a strong status for non-elemental types, where flinch and crits reign supreme. It most notably hands a status to the Normal and Fighting types. I will most likely not make moves like Fake Out have their flinches contribute to the status, but I can still see that as something to leave in to make Fake Out a more potent opening shot. If I did something like that, I'd drop the base damage of the move to keep it from being as good of a revenge kill move to clarify the move's identity as an opening shot / setup rather than a closer.

Some electric status moves will still inflict Paralysis directly. Maybe a fighting status move to inflict this status as well, as this new layout fits nicely with Fighting's identity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912394
Similar to Paralysis, I'm adding routes to status that AREN'T RNG reliant or hard-linked to status moves. Burn, Frostbite, and Poison statuses are inflicted in Tiers, and the current tier is determined by the amount of status points on a Pokemon (invisible value). This makes it possible to use status without forcing the player into status moves. It also greatly rewards committing to a particular status.

>Burn / Frostbite
Identical twins of Status. Fire types are immune to Burn, Ice types are immune to Frostbite.
Burn is inflicted by reaching [threshold] of Burn status points. Fire status moves inflict a set amount of status points, but damaging fire moves also deal some Burn status points. Some Fire moves deal more Burn status, and as a tradeoff deal less direct damage. Same philosophy for Frostbite, but for Ice moves. Ice receives frost status moves a la Will-O-Wisp.
>Tiers - I reached at points = 50% target's maximum HP, II reach at points = 100% target's maximum HP
>I: Moves of the inflicting type (Fire/Ice) deal 25% increased damage. DoT moves (like fire spin) deal 50% increased damage, both on use and on recurring damage. Burnt/Frostbitten Pokemon take 1/16 maximum HP damage per turn, doubled to 1/8 if the afflicted Pokemon would be weak to that elemental type.
>II: Attack (Burn) / Special Attack (Frostbite) lowered 50%, speed lowered 25%. Moves of the inflicting type (Fire/Ice) deal 50% increased damage. Status cures used on Tier II only reset the status to Tier I.

Tiering in this manner makes these statuses excellent on the offense. Elemental moves that push an opponent under the 50% HP line set you up for the finishing stroke the next turn regardless of opponents' recoveries, and opponents that can restore their health to outpace this are eventually forced into Tier II, where they can again be set up for a finishing stroke and are even harder to cleanse of status.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912408
>Poison
Poison and Steel types are immune to Poison
Poison follows the same principles as Burn/Frostbite, wherein a set amount of Poison status points determine the status of the Pokemon.
>Tiers - I reached at points = 30% target's maximum HP, II reached at points = 60% target's maximum HP, Toxic reached at points = 120% of target's maximum HP
>I: Deals a flat amount of Poison damage each turn (as if a low-power Poison move were used against the opponent, rather than a % of maximum HP)
>II: Deals 1/8 maximum HP DoT per turn. Damaging poison moves lower Poisoned Pokemon's Defense and Special Defense 1 stage on hit.
Curing Poison II reverts to Poison I
>Toxic: Takes 1/4 Maximum HP DoT per turn. This damage increases by an additional 1/8 Maximum HP each turn, increasing the Toxic Counter. Curing Toxic reverts to Poison II, but does NOT reset the Toxic Counter.

The best stab I could take at updating Poison to not be just boring chip damage. Tier I is excellent at dealing with squishier Pokemon, with the potential for the flat damage to actually deal MORE than % HP damage would. Tier II is then available if the target is bulkier, and rewards continued use of Poison moves as stat droppers. If the opponent is truly nasty, Toxic comes online and is inevitable, even if the opponent has a way to scrub status.

5/6, missed numbering 4 but oh well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52912485
I suppose I'd refine my goal to be "defining the RNG risk-taker". For example, in the case of Sleep, the Sleep inducer is taking a 75% chance (Sleep Powder, in this instance) that they will cripple their opponent for 2-4 turns. The slept Pokemon now has to take a risk to even play the game further, unless the player switches it out. In most scenarios, 2-4 turns of sleep is a death sentence or a huge setup opportunity, making Sleep basically a higher-accuracy OHKO move with even bigger potential repercussions.
In this scenario, we instead have an immediate payoff for attempting Sleep that still allows the opponent the opportunity to control their Pokemon and assume their own risks without being forced into a specific path. This also means we can heighten the accuracy of Drowsy/Sleep moves, as we no longer have to worry about the feast/famine Sleep moves inherently create. The final rework to Sleep turns means we now have a consistent pattern, with specific, well-defined risks associated with each turn to engage with. Sure, this makes turn 2 a coin-flip, but in reality Sleep was always a series of coinflips - I've simply made the Pokemon more likely to wake, with the downside that they may still lose the turn's move.

Valid. I think you're seeing those parallels as deckbuilding and teambuilding "rhyme" in a lot of ways. The ability to compose a team or deck is limited only by the availability of options, and Pokemon delivers in spades (and just like card games, Pokemon suffers from power creep AND centralizing of the meta to strategies that for the most part call for silver bullets or direct countermeta builds). Pokemon has this easier and harder due to only having six (or 24 if you view it at the movepool-level, or 30 if you include abilities) slots instead of 40+ - not to mention lack of rematches in online play makes it hard to "sideboard" Pokemon.
Similarities, but also signficant differences.

>>52920580
I think this is just a shortcoming of story design. Stories are meant to be played once, and trying to make them replayable carries a lot of pressure. What do you think people would want to try multiple times? Do you lock some of your proudest stuff behind one potential path? How do you cultivate an experience that makes people want to play again, or one that can be played again but was satisfying the first time around?
Really interesting section of design theory, but it does lead to what you said - if you leave a bunch of neat stuff for people to discover, they're gonna want to discover it on the FIRST time around. And locking certain things to a specific path means unless you give the opportunity to come back later, you've effectively deleted a portion of your game from the player's save.
This is particularly exacerbated in the romhacking scene, where there has really been no online multiplayer, so the story has even MORE weight on it to be engaging and interesting in a series that doesn't have enough gametime to show off 500+ Pokemon's unique strengths.
I personally am trying my hand at getting as much information rammed into the game as possible - one of these is an Evolutions Guide in the Pokemon Lab. Consulting the guide for a Pokemon you have seen states, in game-friendly terms, how to get it. Eliminates cumbersome documentation, lets the game stand alone.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52920580
>>52920730
To elaborate on confusion though, I actually thought of it one step further as recoil is nice, but not a perfect fit.
I thought it might be a good idea to make confusion break up the damage a move deals - for example, let's say the Pokemon uses Ember while confused, a 40-power move.
In my setup, damage would be dealt as:
>a 30-power fire move to the opponent
>a 10-power fire move to the confused Pokemon (still on the fence about typing with the "recoil", as it would make confusion better against things like Ghost and Dragon Types, which I'm not mad about)

Naw, just make confusion a flat percentage like 15% or something. Let stats and type matchups take care of the rest, no need to make "more" or "less" confused. Do you think that the creators should also disable the ability to mute audio, because of all the work put into the music and sound effects?

Ever heard of death of the author? It's out of the creator's scope to dictate elements external to their creation beyond mere suggestions.
Even games with heavy reliance on external factors for their intended experience such as horror games intended to be played in the dark or atmospheric games intended to be played with headphones on won't stop someone from not doing what they suggest, because they respect that the player has agency and doesn't need to be policed in order to buy into the experience.
They also know that each player's ideal experience is likely going to deviate from the intended experience in someway, and trust that the player can do their part in creating a good experience because the player knows what their ideal experience is better than the creator does.

>>52929063
>aims to reduce RNG tied to status
>Paralysis now includes increased crit chance

You're over thinking things. Instead, look at what people use the status for. Burn, for example, is used to deal minor damage and to cripple physical attackers. Paralysis is used to slow fast mons to a crawl, poison (especially toxic) is used to deal passive damage. Sleep is used to get free turns. Freeze is bullshit.

The way I would fix status is simple:
1. Only allow dedicated status moves to inflict that status (no 10% Ice Beam freezes). Also, increase the accuracy of TWave, WoW, and Toxic to 100%.
2. Remove the individual instances of RNG from status (paralysis no longer fully paralyzes, sleep always lasts X turns)

That's it. If you want to keep the ability for Scald/Body Slam/Sludge Bomb/other 30% status moves to inflict the status, make it so they only inflict the status if used two turns in a row.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52929287
>Paralysis still has an RNG factor!
By simply augmenting an already RNG-tied trait and removing the cancer that is the 25% chance to not move at all. I perceive this as a net reduction of RNG, and coupled with my other updates it is easily lost in the wash.

>Proposed changes
I understand the simplicity of what you are proposing, but my changes do most of what you state and add unique identities to those statuses. Sleep now gets free turns or acts as a charge-up turn for any move. Paralysis can still be shortcutted, but now can be earned without relying on giving T-Wave to every shitter under the sun. Making status accumulate via points allows us to remove chance to inflict and give players clear paths to inflicting status that don't NEED to be tied to a status move or a diceroll.
I get your attempts to simplify the changes, but despite the amount of text in that image these changes are minor and mostly code-level, with easy-to-implement visual indicators in the battle screen to show weaker players cause-and-effect, while giving them decent depth for stronger players to tinker with strategies.
I hear your advocacy for minimizing the actual changes from vanilla statuses, but I genuinely believe this is a better way to make status intuitive and rewarding at most levels of play.

>>52930807
>The game requires specific Pokemon and strategies for every gym to not get slapped the fuck out
>Even early in the game, parts that are typically reserved for tinkering with team composition
>Hack offers no way to reasonably catch up new catches, does not scale up wild level caps, and expects you to still grab a new Pokemon or three just to beat a gym
My umbrage is not with difficulty, it is with designing teams that MUST have a handful of counters or be overleveled to not get slapped. Coverage is fine - slapping every elemental punch on a level 30 Electabuzz in Gym 3 is not. Pokemon does not need Souls-like design elements where Pokemon are just supercharged ahead of your own, or the base requirement that you MUST grind EVs and have IV manipulation to not have a shitty go of it. It needs unique strategies for you to learn and work around to overcome. A rain team that slaps my ass is going to make me a lot less pissed than that Electabuzz, because although rain has hard counters, you can also take advantage of rain, or side-pivot weather, or brute force if you know the priority targets to pressure out. You can learn how a rain team works and pick it apart - Electabuzz will always have those moves, and you are stuck getting pegged by those punches until you get lucky or play the way the dev wants you to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52930735
There's a lot that can be done to avoid a gym being swept by a single move without needing to give each team member perfect coverage.
An easy example is how in the real games, some Water gyms have a Water/Ground type, but if you look at Crasher Wake or Wallace, that Water/Ground type isn't also packing an Ice move. Instead, that's relegated to another member of the team, and depending on the battle, they also have mons that are neutral to grass moves.

Something like that does a lot to prevent the player from just clicking on a single move through the entire battle, while also not punishing them for actually trying to use a Grass type against a Water/Ground mon only to get blasted by an Ice Beam. The gym should be able to check if a player has a diverse team and force them to actually use it, but giving a gym too much coverage can make the answers far too specific.
